channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-8188] Avoid unnecessary row compare in StoreScanner
item.description:
When scanner batching disable (which is the default) a row compare in StoreScanner avoided, because only entire rows of data are requested.
This provides a slight performance gain, especially for tall tables (and when all data is in the cache)
item.summary: Avoid unnecessary row compare in StoreScanner

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
0.94 patch.
I measure between 3-5% performance increase in my scenarios.

Hi Lars Hofhansl, in which scenario can we have limit < 0? Also, how often? Also, should this parameter be documented in the Javadoc?
JM - when batching is not used in Scan (Scan#setBatch(int)), limit will come into StoreScanner as -1.
Thanks for the clarification Anoop.

Yep. This is documented up in RegionScanner.
The test failures are suspicious. I'll take a look.
Both tests pass locally. Attaching again.

This message is automatically generated.
Patch looks good.
Lars Hofhansl, have you been able to test this specific scenario locally?
Yep. It's mostly apparent when all data is in the block cache.
Any objections to committing this?
not from me. +1 on 0.95 and trunk.

So now that I said this, I have thought of a more radical/experimental change that does away with SQM.setRow(...) altogether.
The first row KV is passed to SQM anyway, so it can avoid another comparison, and also make the logic more self-contained.

Passes:

  • TestQueryMatcher
  • TestFromClientSide
  • TestAtomicOperation
  • My own local performance testing

I am still validating my earlier performance claim.

Please have a look, if you don't think I am crazy I'll make a 0.95/0.96 patch.
Let me just commit the simple part here (which was +1'ed). And file another ticket to simplify ScanQueryMatcher.
Committed (non-experimental version) to 0.94, 0.95, and 0.98.
